column4: I don't recognise the .ecryptfs/wrapped-passphrase stuff, which the server is clearly having a problem with. Whose procedure are you following?
rsa-keygen on server copy id_rsa.pub to client cat id_rsa.pub >> authorized_keys2 as well as authorized_keys
you have client & server backwards above. You keygen on the client & copy its .pub to authorized keys on the server. Was that a typo?
no it wasn't, i thought that might be it and i tried both ways, neither server nor client can ssh into each other
do you have console access to the server? If so, you can run sshd -d to get additional debugging info from the server...
nope just tried again, does ot work
ok lemme try
i see an error that says auth refused: bad ownership or modes for directory /home/user
that's an important clue. So what *are* the permissions on /home/user for your user?
never changed anyhting on home just .ssh. brand new install. according to guys on the site and other sites .ssh moust be 700 and file sinside must be 600
apparently your sshd doesn't agree. For what it's worth, my home dir is drwxr-xr-x and my .ssh is drwx------. How's yours?
home drwxrwxrwx ssh drwx------
anybody can write in your home dir. That will make ssh object. Remove group & other write perms...
work, why the hell does ubuntu do that anyway??
if I knew the answer to that... So is it working?
yup!
one down. 10,0000 to go...
this is a pretty serious design issue
i have seen other sites complain about this too, there is no reason for your home folder to be rw to everyone
Since you're the only one with this particular issue, I think there was something odd about your install...
so what does it not install yr home with full rw to everyone?
I don't think so, but I last installed so long ago & I keep /home across installs, so I can't actually remember. Maybe it's an install bug? Better log messages from sshd would help...
cool thanks man. i will check it out
